(new policy: invite all the peoples, and they can leave if they wants)
self-promotion is my favorite thing in the entire world, but I still find it almost impossible to write a paragraph that doesn't make me cringe when I read it
seeking feedback onnnnn...
LinkedIn profile: <https://www.linkedin.com/in/brandoncurtis>

attachments.text: View Brandon Curtis's professional profile on LinkedIn. LinkedIn is the world's largest business network, helping professionals like Brandon Curtis discover inside connections to recommended job candidates, industry experts, and business partners.
attachments.fallback: View Brandon Curtis's professional profile on LinkedIn. LinkedIn is the world's largest business network, helping professionals like Brandon Curtis discover inside connections to recommended job candidates, industry experts, and business partners.

text: ("professionals like Brandon Curtis" luuuuulz)

comments: maybe change "I want" to "I am seeking" or "I am looking for"?  Also the opening is snappy and powerful, but a little abrupt.  Any way you can turn that sentence around and start with "Making a difference" and then proceed to "technical aptitude is insufficient"? Something like "To make a real difference in the world, technical aptitude alone is insufficient--scientists and engineers need..."

also, you don't want to imply that your technical aptitude is in any way a Priority 2. right now it reads like "I am more skilled at communicating science than I am at doing science!" Clearly not true to anyone who pokes through your CV, but at this point they've only read two sentences, so.
otherwise, great!  Way better than the usual template-matchy descriptions you normally see.
(I'm immersed in this process myself-- academic cover letters are a pain! and everyone has different opinions on how long they should be, what they should address, etc)
(to clarify: I'm way more skilled at communicating science than I am at doing science)
Thanks for the feedback <@U0A6WE73P>, I'll do some more editing and see how it sounds
I made a lot of changes to the organization and language yesterday
1) the paper descriptions were originally just the abstracts, but that was pretty impenetrable → replaced with short descriptions
2) converted a bunch of text blocks into bullets to reduce the visual density
3) moved non- or low-paying stuff, especially team stuff, from 'employment' to 'projects'
'Projects' let you link out directly to the other people on the team, which is cool
4) restructured descriptions to emphasis what I actually did
5) after some deliberation, added skills but turned off skills endorsements
What was the source of the decision on the skills but no endorsements?
I also skill but no endorsements. Mostly because the only people who endorsed me for things don’t know shit about them
Makes sense
agreed, it was weird to have a bunch of randos endorsing me for random things
and if I have 3 endorsements for Python and 15 endorsements for biochemistry, does that make me five times better at biochemistry?
Yes
Obviously
oh good :simple_smile:

Greg Johnson endorsed me for:
 • Carpet Cleaning
 • Shoes
 • Alternative Rock
...Can I get everyone in the room to endorse <@U0A6T0LNT> in "Reading Wikipedia Out Loud"?
(<@U0BTTCL9M> would be on board with that...)
Haha yes
We should have a you tube series...
one time a professional dog walker endorsed me for "analysis"
I didn't know you could turn those off! (goes to linkedin to turn it off)

there is part of me that still wants to believe that no one actually uses linkedin + researchgate + google scholar + all the countless stupid online tools that purport to showcase your professional abilities
i mean, seriously, just look at my damn CV
it's hard enough just doing science, let alone worrying about keeping a dozen professional networking sites updated
Marketing department here is quite fond of LinkedIn... Not sure we've ever used it as part of a recruiting process
We use it as part of our recruiting process and so does everyone else AFAIK
yeah, I don't think I've ever interacted with a recruiter of any sort  (or anyone who had a potential interest in hiring me) and haven't had them stalking my LinkedIn profile by the end of the day
How do you know when someone is looking at your profile?
It will report it to you unless they have the paid anonymity settings
How's the new job, <@U0A6XP8JF>? I haven't heard 'the pitch' yet :simple_smile:
Heh
It's good
No pitch for you. If you want to buy high-fashion clothes on mobile, you can use our app! If you want to do it on the web, you can use our soon-to-launch website.
I'm working on the web side of things
Company is still a startup, but a lot more stable
(revenue?)
There is revenue, but it pales in comparison to our operating cost.
We recently raised a series B round of funding
so a typical startup :simple_smile:
reasonable commute?
yeah, it's in flatiron, so it's pretty close

attachments.text: In anticipation of returning human spaceflight launches to American soil, and in preparation for the agency’s Journey to Mars, NASA announced it will soon begin accepting applications for the next class of astronaut candidates.
